document.docTitle: Isolation and evaluation of virucidal activities of flavanone glycosides and rosmarinic acid derivatives from Dracocephalum spp. against feline calicivirus

paragraph.docTitle:
Isolation and evaluation of virucidal activities of flavanone glycosides and rosmarinic acid derivatives from
Dracocephalum spp.
against feline calicivirus

document.paragraph:
Mirza Synthia Sabrin a, b
, Erdenechimeg Selenge
c , Yohei Takeda d , Javzan Batkhuu e , Haruko Ogawa f , Dulamjav Jamsransuren f , Keisuke Suganuma d, g , Toshihiro Murata h, *

Department of Veterinary Medicine , Obihiro University of Agriculture and Veterinary Medicine , 2-11 Inada , Obihiro , Hokkaido , 080-8555, Japan

subSection.paragraph: Virucidal activity
Feline calicivirus
Flavanone glycoside
Stilbenoid glycoside
Rosmarinic acid
ABSTRACT

Feline calicivirus is one of the surrogate viruses of human norovirus. This study aimed to identify virucidal compounds, chemical constituents of plants from the genus
Dracocephalum
, which are rich in flavonoids and phenylpropanoid oligomers. Four undescribed compounds, including a flavanone glucoside, two stilbenoid glycosides, and a phenylpropanoid amide glycoside, as well as 17 known compounds, were isolated from the Mongolian plants
Dracocephalum fruticulosum Stephan ex Willd.
, and
D. nutans
L. belonging to the family Lamiaceae . The structures of the compounds were determined based on NMR, MS, and electronic CD spectroscopic data. In addition to these 21 compounds, 15 previously reported compounds from
D. foetidum Bunge
in C.F. von Ledebour were included, and a total of 36 compounds were evaluated for their virucidal activities against feline calicivirus. Some of the flavanone glycosides and phenylpropanoid oligomers showed virucidal activities, and their structural features are discussed. The findings suggest that isosakuranetin glycosides and phenylpropanoid oligomers may have the potential for norovirus inactivation.

Seventeen species of the genus
Dracocephalum (Lamiaceae)
are distributed in Mongolia , and many of them are known as medicinal plants ( Ligaa, 2015 ; Ozek ¨et al., 2013;
Selenge et al., 2013
, 2014 ).
D. fruticulosum Steph. ex Willd.
is called “Jivzipriyangu,” and its medicinal preparations are used in traditional Mongolian medicine for the treatment of liver disease, wounds, and blood clots ( Ligaa, 2015 ).
D . nutans
L. is called “priyangku” in Tibetan medicine, and its medicinal preparations are used internally for abdominal and kidney inflammation ( Ligaa, 2015 ). Essential oils are one of the features of various
Dracocephalum spp.
plants, and cis -chrysanthenol acetate and trans -verbenol from
D . fruticulosum
(Ozek ¨et al., 2013), as well as pinocamphone and β- pinene from
D . nutans
, were reported as chemical constituents of volatile oils ( Baiseitova et al., 2015 ; Misra et al., 1988 ).
D . foetidum Bunge
in C.F.von Ledebour is a medicinal plant used for the treatment of inflammation, and monoterpene glycosides, phenylpropanoid oligomers, and flavonoids were identified in this plant in a previous study (
Selenge et al., 2014
).

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. E-mail address: murata-t@tohoku-mpu.ac.jp (T. Murata).

subSection.paragraph:
Hence, to find effective norovirus-inactivating materials with no adverse effects on human health, we focused on plant-derived components. We have previously reported ( Takeda et al., 2020 ) that components derived from the Mongolian herbal plant
Saxifraga spinulosa
, including flavonoids and galloyl glycosides ( Badral et al., 2017 ), showed virucidal activities against feline calicivirus (FCV), which is known as one of the surrogates of human norovirus, murine norovirus, influenza A virus, and SARS-CoV-2.

In this study, we focused on Mongolian plants of the genus
Dracocephalum
as potential sources of candidate antiviral compounds.
The ECD spectrum of 5 was close to that of 1 , which indicated that C-2 of 5 was also in the ( S )-absolute configuration.

The molecular formula of 19 was determined to be C 27 H 34 O 14 based on HRFABMS data (positive): m / z 583.2028 [M+H] + (calcd for C H O: 583.2027). In the 1 H NMR spectrum of 19 (DMSO‑ d , 27 35 14 6 Table 1 ), two sets of aromatic proton resonances ( δH 6.99, 2H, brd, J = 8.5 Hz, H-3 and H-5 and 7.09, 2H, brd, J = 6.5 Hz, H-2 and H-6) and ( δH 6.68, 1H, d, J = 7.5 Hz, H-10, 7.15, 1H, dd, J = 8.0, 7.5 Hz, H-11, and 6.72, 1H, d, J = 8.0 Hz, H-12) were observed, and the former and latter coupling system protons suggested the presence of a p -substituted benzene ring and trisubstituted benzene ring moieties, respectively. The aromatic carbons [ δC 135.1 (C-1), 128.8 (C-2 and C-6), 116.4 (C-3 and C-5), 155.6 (C-4), 141.0 (C-9), 120.1 (C-10), 130.6 (C-11), 113.9 (C-12), 156.8 (C-13), and 119.9 (C-14)] were assigned to the two benzene rings by heteronuclear multiple quantum coherence (HMQC) and HMBC correlations ( Fig. 4 ). In the aliphatic field of the 1 H NMR spectrum, two methylene protons at δH 2.75 (2H, m, H-7) and 2.88 (2H, m, H-8) were observed and their coupling with each other was confirmed by the 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum of 19 . This result suggested the presence of an – CH 2 - CH 2 - moiety. In the HMBC spectrum of 19 , H-7 was long-range coupled with C-2 and C-6, and H-8 was coupled with C-10 and C-14, showing a dihydrostylbene skeleton. The carbonyl carbon at δC 170.5 (C-15) had no HMBC correlation, and it was hypothesized that the carbonyl group was bonded to C-14 compared to lunularic acid ( Nguyen et al., 2006 ). The HMBC correlations from H-11 to C-9 and the oxygenated carbon (C-13) and H-10 and H-12 to C-14 supported this conclusion. These data showed that 19 had a 4- O -13-hydroxy-14-carboxydihydrostylbene moiety as its aglycone ( Fig. 4 ). In the 13 C NMR spectrum of 19 , 12 oxygenated carbon resonances were observed at δC 99.3, 82.8, 76.1, 69.4, 76.9, 60.6 (C-Glc-1 – 6) and δC 104.6, 74.8, 75.9, 69.6, 76.8, 60.6 (C-Glc-II-1 – 6), and these data showed the presence of two glycosyl moieties ( Agrawal 1992 ; Selenge et al., 2013 ). HPLC sugar analysis of 19 after acid hydrolysis suggested that the sugar units were D-glucopyranose. The coupling constants of the anomeric protons of H-Glc-1 ( J = 7.0 Hz) and H-Glc-II-1 ( J = 8.0 Hz) showed β- configurations. In the HMBC spectrum, the H-Glc-II-1 proton resonance at δH 4.48 (1H, d, J = 8.0 Hz) was long-range coupled with C-Glc-2, and H-Glc-1 at δH 4.91 (1H, d, J = 7.0 Hz) was coupled with C-4. Therefore, 19 was determined to be 2-hydroxy-6-{2-[4- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl(1 → 2)- O -β- D-glucopyranosylphenyl] ethyl}benzoic acid, as shown in Fig. 1 .

The molecular formula of 20 was assigned to be C 27 H 34 O 15 based on HRFABMS data (positive): m / z 599.1982 [M+H] + (calcd for C 27 H 35 O 15 : 599.1976), including one more oxygen atom than in 19 . In the 1 H NMR spectrum of 20 (methanol- d 4 , Table 1 ), the o - and/or m -coupling pattern protons ( δH 6.72, 1H, d, J = 2.0 Hz, H-2; 7.16, 1H, d, J = 8.0 Hz, H-5; 6.62, 1H, d, J = 8.0, 2.0 Hz H-6) showed the presence of an m , p - dioxygenated benzene ring moiety. The hydroxy proton resonance at δH 7.85 was observed in the 1 H NMR spectrum of 20 (DMSO‑ d 6 , Table 1 ), suggesting the presence of an additional hydroxy group compared to 19 . The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra were similar to those of 19 , except for the presence of an m , p -dioxygenated benzene ring instead of the p -oxygenated benzene ring of 19 . These MS and NMR data suggested that the aglycone of 20 was a 4- O -3,13-dihydroxy-14-carboxydihydrostylbenoid moiety ( Fig. 4 ). In the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 4 ), H-Glc-II-1 ( δH 4.74, 1H, d, J = 7.5 Hz) was long-range coupled with C-Glc-2 ( δC 83.5), and H-Glc-1 ( δH 4.72, 1H, d, J = 7.5 Hz) was coupled with C-4 ( δC 145.2). These correlations showed the presence of a 4- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl(1 → 2)- O - β- D-glucopyranosyl moiety. The nuclear Overhauser effect correlation between H-Glc-1 and H-5 ( δH 7.16, 1H, d, J = 8.0 Hz) supported the bonding of the glucosyl moiety to C-4 ( Fig. 4 ). Therefore, 20 was determined to be 2-{2-[3-hydroxy-4- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl(1 → 2)- O - β- D-glucopyranosyl-phenyl]ethyl}-6-hydroxybenzoic acid, as shown in Fig. 1 .

caption.paragraph: NMR spectroscopic data for compounds 1 , 19 , and 20 .

tableNote.paragraph: 6 c Unclear signal pattern due to overlapping.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Key heteronuclear multiple bond (HMBC) correlations of compound 1 .
Fig. 3. Electronic CD spectra of compounds 1 and 5 .

subSection.paragraph: The HRFABMS data (positive) of 21 ( m / z 822.3188 [M+H] + , calcd for C 39 H 51 NO 18 : 822.3185) showed that the molecular formula of 21 was C 39 H 50 NO 18 . In the 1 H NMR spectrum of 21 , three sets of aromatic proton resonances ( δH 7.03, 2H, d, J = 8.5 Hz, H-3 and H-5 and 7.19, 2H, d, J = 8.5 Hz, H-2 and H-6), ( δH 7.53, 2H, overlapping, H-2 ′ and H-6 ′ , 7.37, 3H, overlapping, H-3 ′ , H-4 ′ , and H-5 ′ ), and ( δH 7.51, 1H, d, J = 16.0 Hz, H-7 ′ and 6.56, 1H, d, J = 16.0 Hz, H-8 ′ ) were observed. The carbonyl carbon at δC 168.7 (C-9 ′ ) and the HMBC correlation from H-8 ′ to C-1 ′ ( δC 136.4) showed the presence of a cinnamoyl moiety ( Fig. 4 ). The coupling constant between H-7 ′ and H-8 ′ ( J = 16.0 Hz) showed their E -configuration. In the aliphatic field of 1 H NMR, proton resonances of – CH 2 - CH 2 - moiety ( δH 2.82, 2H, brt, J = 7.0 Hz, H-7 and 3.52, 2H, overlapping, H-8) were observed, and H-7 was long-range coupled with C-1, C-2, and C-6. These data suggested the presence of a p -substituted phenylethyl moiety. The presence of one nitrogen was indicated by HRFABMS. The chemical shift value of C-8 ( δC 42.4) suggested that C-8 bonded to a nitrogen. The H-8 proton was long-range coupled with the C-9 ′ carbonyl carbon of amide. These data showed that the aglycone of 21 was (2 E )- N -[2-(4-hydroxyphenyl)ethyl]-3-phenyl-2-propenamide. The three anomeric proton resonances ( δH 5.73, 1H, d, J = 1.5 Hz, H-Rha-1; 4.61, 1H, d, J = 7.5 Hz, H-Glc-I-1; 4.43, 1H, d, J = 8.0 Hz, H-Glc-II-1) were observed in the 1 H NMR spectrum of 21 . The homonuclear Hartmann–Hahn (HOHAHA) spectra showed spin system protons from each anomeric proton, as discussed below. Their corresponding carbons were assigned by HMQC spectrum of 21 . These suggested the presence of one rhamnosyl and two glucosyl moieties ( Agrawal 1992 ; Selenge et al., 2014 ). The peaks of L-rhamnopyranose and D-glucopyranose derivatives were confirmed by HPLC sugar analysis after acid hydrolysis. The α- and β- orientations of L-rhamnopyranosyl and D-glucopyranosyls were determined by their coupling constants J = 1.5 Hz and 7.5–8.0 Hz, respectively. The HMBC correlations from H-Rhm-2 ( δH 4.35, 1H, dd, J = 3.0, 1.5 Hz) to C-Glc-I-1 ( δC 105.9), H-Glc-I-1 to C-Rha-2 ( δC 79.9), H-Rhm-3 ( δH 4.16, 1H, dd, J = 10.0, 3.0 Hz) to C-Glc-II-1 ( δC 106.6), and H-Glc-II-1 to C-Rha-3 ( δC 79.6) showed that the sugar chain was O -β- D-glucopyranosyl-(1 → 2)-[ O -β- D-glucopyranoside-(1 → 3)]- O -α- L-rhamnopyranosyl. In addition, there were two acetyl groups in 21 ( δH 2.00, 3H, s; 2.09, 3H, s; δC 172.7; 21.1). The lower field shifted oxymethylene resonances ( δH 4.36, 1H, dd, J = 12.0, 2.0 Hz and 4.31, 1H, dd, J = 12.0, 6.5 Hz) were assigned to H-Glc-II-6 protons by the below procedure. In the HOHAHA spectra, when H-Glc-II-1 ( δH 4.43) was irradiated, the correlation with H-Glc-II-5 ( δH 3.51) was shown. Moreover, the H-Glc-II-5 proton correlated with the H-Glc-II-6 protons in the 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum. In the HMBC spectrum, H-Rha-4 ( δH 5.11, 1H, t, J = 10.0 Hz) and H-Glc-II-6 ( δH 4.31, 1H, dd, J = 12.0, 6.5 Hz) were long-range coupled with the carbonyl carbons of the acetyl groups. The lower shifted carbon resonances ( δC 73.7, C-Rha-4; 64.9, C-Glc-II-6) supported this conclusion. Based on these data, 21 was determined to be (2 E )- N -{2-[4- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl-(1 → 2)-[ O -β- D-(6- O -acetyl)glucopyranosyl-(1 → 3)]- O -α- L-(4- O -acetyl)rhamnopyranosyl]ethyl}-3-phe nyl-2-propenamide.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Key heteronuclear multiple bonds (HMBC) and nuclear Overhauser effect (NOE) correlations of compounds 19–21 .

subSection.paragraph:
FCV-inactivating activities of the compounds derived from
D. fruticulosum
,
D . nutans
, and
D . foetidum
( 1–36 ) were evaluated. Among the 10
D. fruticulosum
-derived compounds ( 1–4 , 8 , 9 , 15–18 ), treatment with 1 , 2 , 3 , 15 , 16 , and 17 resulted in lower viral titers than that in the dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) group after 48 h of incubation, which indicated that these compounds had virucidal activity ( Fig. 5A ). Moreover, 1 , 2 , and 17 showed virucidal activities after 6 h of incubation. The reduction in viral titer compared to the DMSO group, which was the value of Y-axis [log 10 50% tissue culture infective dose (TCID 50 )/ml] in the DMSO group minus that value in each test compound group, was 1.63, 1.25, and 1.80 log 10 TCID 50 /ml in groups 1 , 2 , and 17 , respectively. The virucidal activities of these three compounds seemed to be comparable ( Fig. 5B ). On the other hand, the viral titers in groups 4 , 8 , 9 , and 18 were comparable to those in the DMSO group after 48 h of incubation, which indicated that these compounds did not have virucidal activity ( Fig. S2A ). Among the 12
D. nutans
-derived compounds ( 5–7 , 10–15 , and 19–21 ), 5 , 7 , and 15 showed virucidal activities after 48 h of incubation. The reduction in viral titer compared to the DMSO group was 1.13, 1.30, and ≥2.17 log 10 TCID 50 /ml in groups 5 , 7 , and 15 , respectively ( Fig. 5C ). However, these compounds did not show virucidal activity after 6 h of incubation ( Fig. 5D ), whereas 6 , 10–14 , and 19–21 showed no virucidal activity even after 48 h of incubation ( Fig. S2B ). Among the 15
D. foetidum
-derived compounds, 22 and 25 showed virucidal activities after 48 h of incubation. The reduction in viral titer compared to the DMSO group was ≥1.83 and ≥2.17 log 10 TCID 50 /ml in groups 22 and 25 , respectively ( Fig. 5E ). However, these compounds did not show virucidal activity after 6 h of incubation ( Fig. 5F ), whereas 23 , 24 , and 26–36 showed no virucidal activity even after 48 h of incubation ( Fig. S2C ).

Some early research showed that naturally occurring dietary flavonoids possessed antiviral activities against several human viruses ( Kaul et al., 1985 ). In addition, many studies have shown multiple antiviral mechanisms of flavonoids, such as virucidal action against extracellular virions, blocking of virus entry into a cell, and inhibition of viral enzymatic activities essential for viral replication ( Evers et al., 2005 ; Ninfali et al., 2020 ). In our study, a total of 21 flavonoids derived from
D. fruticulosum
,
D . nutans
, and
D . foetidum
were tested for FCV-inactivating activity, and only 5 of them ( 1–3 , 5 , and 7 ) showed antiviral activities. In particular, 1 and 2 may have more potent virucidal activities than those of other flavonoids because these two compounds showed virucidal activity after 6 h of incubation. Thus, flavanones ( 1–3 and 5 ) were more effective against FCV than flavones ( 6–14 and 27–33 ), and flavanone glucosides ( 1–3 and 5 ) showed higher activities than that of naringenin ( 4 ). Although 0.5 mM naringenin ( 4 ) did not show any virucidal activities against FCV and murine norovirus after 2 h of incubation ( Su and D’ Souza, 2013 ), antiviral activities of naringenin ( 4 ) were reported against dengue virus (FrabasileKoishi et al., 2017; Zandi et al.,), zika virus ( Cataneo et al., 2019 ), and hepatitis C virus ( Nahmias et al., 2008 ). As the isolated 4 ′ - O -methyl naringenin (isosakuranetin) glycosides ( 1 and 2 ) showed higher activities than that of naringenin ( 4 ), they may have the potential to be used as virucidal compounds.

In addition, we found five rosmarinic acid-related virucidal compounds, namely, 15–17 , 22 , and 25 . Rosmarinic acid ( 15 ) is known to have antiviral, anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, and antioxidant activities ( Lin et al., 2019 ; Petersen and Simmonds, 2003 ). Compounds 16 , 17 , and 22 are typical rosmarinic acid derivatives. Interestingly, 25 is a rosmarinic acid glucoside. As the acylated rosmarinic acid glucosides ( 23 and 24 ) and the Z -rosmarinic acid glucoside ( 26 ) did not show activity, the effect of the glucosyl moiety remains uncertain. Phenylpropanoid oligomers have been isolated from various plants of the family Lamiaceae ( Murata et al., 2010 , 2021 ). In addition to the virucidal activity of rosmarinic acid, antiviral activities have been reported for caffeic acid derivatives. For example, some caffeic acid oligomers from
Mesona chinensis
showed antiviral activities against the respiratory syncytial virus ( Wang et al., 2020 ). Rosmarinic acid and its derivatives are known to have tannin-like activity ( Petersen and Simmonds, 2003 ), and the results of this study revealed potentially broader antiviral activity spectra of phenylpropanoid oligomers.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 5. Feline calicivirus (FCV)-inactivating activities of
Dracocephalum spp.
-derived compounds. Compounds isolated from
D. fruticulosum
( A and B ),
D . nutans
( C and D ), and
D . foetidum
( E and F ) were incubated with FCV suspensions for 48 h ( A , C , and E ) and 6 h ( B , D , and F ), respectively. Viral titer data are presented as the mean ± standard deviation (n = 3–7 per group). *
p <
0.05; **
p <
0.01 vs. the dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) control group (Student’ s t -test). TCID 50 , 50% tissue culture infectious dose.

subSection.paragraph:
An undescribed isosakuranetin glucoside was isolated from
D. fruticulosum
. Furthermore, undescribed compounds, including two stilbene glycosides and a phenylpropanoid amide glycoside, were obtained from
D. nutans
. Virucidal activities against FCV, a surrogate viruses of human norovirus, were evaluated for a total of 36 compounds, including flavonoids, flavonoid glycosides, phenylpropanoids, phenylpropanoid glycosides, a benzyl glucoside, and monoterpene glycosides, from three
Dracocephalum spp.
plants. Among these compounds, isosakuranetin and naringenin glycosides and phenylpropanoid oligomers, including rosmarinic acid, schizotenuin A, and lycopic acid A, showed virucidal activities. These results suggested the potential for the flavanone glycosides and phenylpropanoid oligomers to be used for norovirus inactivation.

Optical rotations were recorded on a P-2300 polarimeter (JASCO Corp., Tokyo, Japan ). UV spectra were recorded on an MPS-2450 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Kyoto , Japan ). ECD spectra were recorded on a J-700 spectropolarimeter (JASCO). 1 H NMR (400 MHz) and 13 C NMR (100 MHz), 1 H– 1 H COSY, HMQC (optimized for 1 J C-H = 145 Hz), and HMBC (optimized for n J C-H = 8 Hz) spectra were recorded on a JNM-AL400 FT-NMR spectrometer (Jeol, Ltd., Tokyo , Japan ), HOHAHA spectra were recorded on a JNM-LAMBDA400 FT-NMR spectrometer (Jeol, Ltd., Tokyo , Japan ), NOE spectra were recorded using a JEOL JNM-EX270 FT-NMR spectrometer, and chemical shifts are provided as δ values with TMS as an internal standard. HRFABMS data were obtained on a JMS700 mass spectrometer (Jeol, Ltd.) using either m -nitrobenzyl alcohol or a glycerol matrix. A porous polymer gel (Diaion HP-20; Mitsubishi Chemical Co., Tokyo , Japan ) was used for column chromatography. Preparative HPLC was performed on a JASCO 2089 instrument (columns: TSKgel ODS-120T, 21.5 × 300 mm , Tosoh, Tokyo , Japan ; Cosmosil AR-II, 20 × 250 mm , Nacalai Tesque, Kyoto , Japan ; Cosmosil 5 PE-MS, 20 × 250 mm , Nacalai Tesque; Develosil C 30 -UG-5, 20 × 250 mm , Nomura Chemical Aichi , Japan ; Mightysil RP-18 GP, 10 × 250 mm , Kanto Chemical Co., Inc., Tokyo , Japan ) with UV detection at 210 nm .

Aerial parts of
Dracocephalum fruticulosum Steph. ex Willd. (Lamiaceae)
were collected in
July 2006
in Mongolia (
46 ◦ 02.256 ′ N
;
102 ◦ 20.527 ′ E
)
.
Prof. Ch. Sanchir from the Institute of Botany , Mongolian Academy of Sciences , identified the plant species. A voucher specimen (N◦ 90.7.5.06B) was deposited at the herbarium of the Laboratory of Bioorganic Chemistry and Pharmacognosy, National University of Mongolia
.

Aerial parts of
Dracocephalum nutans
L. ( Lamiaceae ) were collected in
July 2010
in Mongolia (
49 ◦ 58.23 ′ N
;
92 ◦ 02.809 ′ E
)
.
Prof. Ch. Sanchir from the Institute of Botany , Mongolian Academy of Sciences , identified the plant species. A voucher specimen (N◦ 90.7.11.16A) was deposited at the herbarium of the Laboratory of Bioorganic Chemistry and Pharmacognosy, National University of Mongolia
.

Dried aerial parts of
D. fruticulosum
( 40 g ) were extracted with acetone/H 2 O (4:1) (1L × 2) at room temperature for a total of 4 weeks. The crude extract ( 7.24 g ) was obtained after concentration, and the extract residue was dissolved in H 2 O; the aqueous solution was subjected to chromatography on a porous polymer gel (Diaion HP- 20, 200 g ) and eluted with H 2 O (fraction 1A, 3.99 g ), MeOH/H 2 O (1:1) (fraction 1B, 1.18 g ), and MeOH (fraction 1C, 1.22 g ). Fraction 1B was subjected to chromatography on an ODS-SM-50C-M column (Yamazen Co., Osaka , Japan ) and eluted with 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O to obtain compounds 8 (8.0 mg), 9 ( 18.5 mg ), and 15 ( 51.1 mg ). Fraction 1C was subjected to chromatography on an ODS-SM-50C-M column and eluted with 50% CH 3 CN/H 2 O (fractions 2A–2L). Fraction 2C (58.0 mg) was subjected to HPLC [AR-II column; mobile phase: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)] to yield compound 2 ( 15.9 mg ). Fraction 2D ( 185.8 mg ) was subjected to HPLC (AR-II column; mobile phase: 25% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA; 5 PE-MS column; mobile phase: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA) to yield compounds 15 ( 45.6 mg ), 17 ( 5.5 mg ), and 18 ( 2.8 mg ). Fraction 2H ( 70.2 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [AR-II column; mobile phase: 30–35% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compound 3 . Fraction 2I ( 97.2 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [AR-II column; mobile phase: 35% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA; Mightysil RP-18 column; mobile phase: 30% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compounds 1 ( 4.6 mg ), 4 ( 39.8 mg ), and 16 ( 3.8 mg ).

Dried aerial parts of
D. nutans
( 50 g ) were extracted with acetone/ H 2 O (4:1) (1L × 2) at room temperature for a total of 7 weeks. The crude extract ( 7.83 g ) was obtained after concentration, and the extract residue was dissolved in H 2 O; the aqueous solution was subjected to chromatography on a porous polymer gel (Diaion HP- 20, 200 g ) and eluted with H 2 O (fraction 3A, 3.91 g ), MeOH/H 2 O (1:1) (fraction 3B, 1.09 g ), and MeOH (fraction 3C, 1.46 g ). Fraction 3B was subjected to chromatography on an ODS column (TSK-gel, ODS-120T) and eluted with 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O (fractions 4A–4O). Fractions 4C and 4D ( 169.8 mg ) were subjected to HPLC (Develosil C 30 column; mobile phase: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA) to yield compound 12 ( 66.4 mg ). Fractions 4E–4G ( 193.3 mg ) were subjected to HPLC (Develosil C 30 column; mobile phase: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA) to yield compounds 5 ( 6.3 mg ) and 15 ( 32.7 mg ). Fractions 4I and 4J (25.0 mg) were subjected to HPLC [Mightysil RP-18 column; mobile phase: 30% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compounds 19 ( 2.7 mg ) and 20 ( 2.3 mg ). Fraction 3C was subjected to chromatography on an ODS column (TSK-gel, ODS-120T) and eluted with 20%–30% CH 3 CN/H 2 O (fractions 5A-5M). Fraction 5C ( 55.3 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [5 PE-MS column; mobile phase: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield 15 ( 17.6 mg ). Fraction 5D ( 55.3 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [5 PE-MS column; mobile phase: 25% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compounds 14 ( 7.3 mg ) and 19 ( 2.5 mg ). Fraction 5E ( 31.3 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [Develosil C 30 column; mobile phases: 25% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compound 20 (3.0 mg). Fraction 5F (35.0 mg) was subjected to HPLC [Develosil C 30 column; mobile phase: 25% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compound 10 (10.0 mg). Fraction 5H (126.0 mg) was subjected to HPLC [Develosil C 30 , column; mobile phases: 20% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compounds 7 ( 9.7 mg ) and 13 ( 4.4 mg ). Fraction 5J ( 84.2 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [Develosil C 30 column; mobile phases: 30% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compound 6 ( 21.2 mg ). Fraction 5K ( 50.6 mg ) was subjected to HPLC [Develosil C 30 column; mobile phase: 35% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA] to yield compounds 11 ( 6.1 mg ) and 21 (9.0 mg).

(2 S )-Isosakuranetin 7- O -β- D-(6 ′′ - O -malonyl)glucopyranoside ( 1 ): Colorless amorphous solid, HR-FAB-MS (positive): m / z 535.1455 [M+H] + (Calcd for C 25 H 27 O 13 : 535.1451). [α] 26 D 38.5 ( c 0.40, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max 284, 324; ECD ( c 0.0002, MeOH) nm ([ θ ]) 215 (26400), 234 (600), 248 (8500), 286 (26100), 333 (7000) nm; 1 H-NMR: (CD 3 OD, 400 MHz and DMSO‑ d 6 , 400 MHz), Table 1 . 13 C-NMR: (CD 3 OD, 100 MHz), Table 1 .

2-Hydroxy-6-{2-[4- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl(1 → 2)- O -β- D-glucopyranosylphenyl]ethyl}benzoic acid ( 19 ): Colorless amorphous solid, HR-FAB-MS (positive): m / z 583.2028 [M+H] + (Calcd for C 27 H 35 O 14 : 583.2027). [α] 25 D 19.3 ( c 0.27, MeOH); 1 H-NMR: (DMSO‑ d 6 , 400 MHz), Table 1 . 13 C-NMR: (DMSO‑ d 6 , 100 MHz), Table 1 .

2-{2-[3-Hydroxy-4- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl(1 → 2)- O -β- D-glucopyranosyl-phenyl]ethyl}-6-hydroxybenzoic acid ( 20 ): Colorless amorphous solid, HR-FAB-MS (positive): m / z 599.1982 [M+H] + (Calcd for C 27 H 35 O 15 : 599.1976). [α] 25 D 11.3 ( c 0.32, MeOH); 1 H-NMR: (CD 3 OD, 400 MHz and DMSO‑ d 6 , 400 MHz), Table 1 . 13 C-NMR: (CD 3 OD, 100 MHz), Table 1 .

Compounds 1 ( 0.5 mg ), 19 (1.0 mg), 20 ( 0.9 mg ), and 21 ( 1.8 mg ) were hydrolyzed with 3.5 N HCl (0.5 ml) at 60 ◦ C for 3 h. The reaction mixtures were subjected to chromatography on an HP-20 resin column (5 × 50 mm ), and water eluates (5 ml) were concentrated. Each residue was stirred with L-cysteine methyl ester (2, 3, 2, and 2 mg , respectively) and O -tolyl isothiocyanate (5 μl) in pyridine (0.5 ml), using a previously reported procedure ( Tanaka et al., 2007 ).

The reaction mixtures were analyzed by HPLC [J-Pak Symphonia C18 column, 4.6 × 250 nm ; mobile phase: 25% CH 3 CN/H 2 O containing 0.2% TFA at 1.0 ml/min; detection at 250 nm ]. D-Glucose ( t R = 27.1 min) in 1 , 19 , 20 , and 21 and L-rhamnose ( t R = 46.2 min) in 21 were identified as their glycosidic moieties, based on comparisons with authentic samples of a D-glucose derivative ( t R = 27.1 min), an L-glucose derivative ( t R = 24.6 min), and an L-rhamnose derivative ( t R = 46.2 min).

Crandell–Rees feline kidney (CRFK) cells and FCV (F9 strain) were provided by Dr. K. Maeda ( Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi , Japan ). CRFK cells were not tested for mycoplasma infection. They were cultured in the viral growth medium after FCV inoculation, as previously described ( Takeda et al., 2020 ). After 3 days of incubation, the supernatant of the cell culture medium containing FCV was collected and used for the FCV suspension. The viral titers of the FCV suspensions were 3.25–5.75 log 10 TCID 50 /ml. The
Dracocephalum spp.
-derived compounds at a concentration of 25 μg/ml or DMSO, used as the solvent control, were added to the FCV suspensions. All FCV suspensions were incubated at 25 ◦ C for 6 and 48 h. After incubation, these suspensions were inoculated into CRFK cells, and 10-fold serial dilutions were performed in the cell culture medium. Three days later, their cytopathic effects on FCV-infected cells were observed, and the viral titers (log 10 TCID 50 /ml) were calculated using the Behrens–Karber ¨method (Karber ¨, 1931). The differences in the titers of FCV suspensions in each test group vs. the DMSO group were evaluated as previously described ( Takeda et al., 2020 ).

The student’ s t -test was performed to analyze the statistical significance of the difference in viral titer between each test compound group and the DMSO group. P values < 0.05 were considered statistically significant.
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

We thank Mr. S. Sato, and Mr. T. Matsuki of Tohoku Pharmaceutical University, for assisting with the MS measurements. We also thank Sachiko Matsuda of Obihiro University of Agriculture and Veterinary Medicine for her technical assistance. We are grateful to Dr. K. Maeda ( Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi , Japan ) for providing FCV (F9 strain) and CRFK cells. We are grateful to Dr. F. Yoshizaki and Dr. K. Sasaki, for providing us with valuable advice. This work was supported by a grant from JSPS Kakenhi (grant number 21H02638, 19 K16397 ). This work was partially supported by an Advanced Research Grant from the National University of Mongolia, the Kanno Foundation of Japan , the Cooperative Research Grant (31-joint-5) of National Research Center for Protozoan Diseases, Obihiro University of Agriculture and Veterinary Medicine, and JST/JICA SATREPS (JPMJSA1906). We would like to thank Editage (www.editage.com) for English language editing.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112896.
